title: 112_hr3117
content: The Act is titled the "Permanent Electronic Duck Stamp Act of 2012" and includes definitions. The "Permanent Electronic Duck Stamp Act of 2012" defines terms such as "actual stamp" as a paper Federal migratory-bird hunting stamp, "automated licensing system" as an electronic system for issuing licenses, and "electronic stamp" as a digital version of the actual stamp. The "Permanent Electronic Duck Stamp Act of 2012" defines an electronic stamp as a unique identifier issued through a state automated licensing system for hunting licenses. The "Permanent Electronic Duck Stamp Act of 2012" defines an electronic stamp as a unique identifier issued through a state automated licensing system for hunting licenses. The electronic stamp must be compatible with the hunting licensing system of the issuing State and described in the approved State application by the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary may authorize any State to issue electronic stamps in accordance with this Act, in consultation with State management agencies. The Secretary must approve a State's application to issue electronic stamps under this Act. The application must include details on the stamp format, fees, accounting process, data transmission to the Secretary, and stamp delivery method. The Secretary can determine the number of new States participating in the program each year. The State must transfer collected amounts to the Secretary, transmit stamp customer data electronically, deliver actual stamps, issue duplicate electronic stamps, and provide any other required information. The Secretary will publish deadlines, eligibility requirements, and selection criteria for applications under this section. SEC. 5. STATE OBLIGATIONS AND AUTHORITIES. The Secretary mandates that individuals purchasing electronic stamps from a State must receive an actual stamp before the electronic stamp expires. States must provide customer information and revenue from electronic stamp sales to the Secretary, including buyer details and stamp values. The Secretary requires States to submit information on electronic stamp sales, including stamp values and buyer details. States can charge a fee for issuing electronic stamps and provide duplicate stamps if needed. This section does not apply to State fees collected separately. (d) Duplicate Electronic Stamps - States can issue duplicate electronic stamps to replace lost or damaged ones. (e) Limitation on State License Purchase - States cannot require individuals to buy a hunting license to get an electronic stamp under this Act. SEC. 6. ELECTRONIC STAMP REQUIREMENTS; RECOGNITION OF ELECTRONIC STAMP. The Secretary shall require an electronic stamp issued by a State to have the same format as any other license and specify identifying features of the licensee. The electronic stamp bestows the same privileges as an actual stamp, is recognized nationally, and authorizes hunting in other states. It is valid for a period agreed upon, not exceeding 45 days. The authority of a State to issue electronic stamps under this Act may be terminated by the Secretary if the State violates the terms approved by the Secretary, or by the State itself with written notice to the Secretary.
